{{Infobox musical artist | name = The Beat Fleet | image = TheBeatFleet-Mocvara.jpg | alt = | caption = TBF members in concert at Močvara club in [[Zagreb]] in November 2009, when they recorded their live album ''[[Perpetuum Fritule]]''. | image_size = | background = group_or_band | alias = TBF | origin = [[Split, Croatia|Split]], [[Croatia]] | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip-hop]], [[rap-rock]] | years_active = {{Start date|1997}}–present | label = [[Croatia Records|Croatia]] (1997–1999)
[[Menart Records|Menart]] (1999–2009)
[[Dallas Records|Dallas]] (2009–present) | associated_acts = Alejuandro Buendija, Leut Magnetik, ST!llness, Sinestet | website = | current_members = Aleksandar Antić
Mladen Badovinac
Luka Barbić
Ognjen Pavlović
Nikša Mandalinić
Nikola Vidović | past_members = Nikola Čelan (1990–1994)
Sveslav Vrandečić
Nikola Luša
[[Dragan Lukić Lvky]]
Edi Grubišić
Jan Ivelić
Petar Radanović }} '''The Beat Fleet''', also known as '''TBF''', is a band from [[Split (city)|Split]], [[Croatia]], founded in 1990. Members of the band are: Aleksandar Antić (vocals, lyrics, samples, harmonica), Mladen Badovinac (vocal, samples), Luka Barbić (vocals, keyboards, samples), Ognjen Pavlović (bass guitar), Nikša Mandalinić, (electric guitar), Nikola Vidović (drums). They published six albums. The Beat Fleet are widely considered to be one of the most innovative experimental bands in Croatia and wider area. They are heavily influenced by [[reggae]], the British [[trip hop]] scene, electronic and experimental music. With years their built new style of music was named Ping Pong. Ping pong is mixture of [[reggae]], [[afro beat]], [[hip hop]], [[rap rock]], [[alternative rock]], [[Dub music|dub]] and British [[trip hop]]. == Discography == * ''Ping-Pong (Umjetnost zdravog đira)'' (1997, [[Croatia Records]]) * ''[[Uskladimo toplomjere]]'' (2000, [[Menart Records]]) * ''[[Maxon Universal]]'' (2004, Menart Records) * ''[[Galerija Tutnplok]]'' (2007, Menart Records) * ''[[Perpetuum Fritule]]'' (2010, [[Dallas Records]] - live album) * ''[[Pistaccio Metallic]]'' (2011, Dallas Records) * ''[[Danas sutra]]'' (2015, Dallas Records) ==External links== {{Commons category|The Beat Fleet}} *[http://www.facebook.com/pages/TBF-Official-FanClub/313381382011333 Official FanPage on Facebook] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051029081121/http://www.tbf.dalmatino.de/ Official website] {{hr icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090710184901/http://www.thebeatfleet.com/ The Beat Fleet] {{hr icon}} *{{Discogs artist|The Beat Fleet}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beat Fleet, The}} [[Category:Croatian hip hop groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1990]] [[Category:Musicians from Split, Croatia]] {{Croatia-stub}} {{hiphop-band-stub}}

{{Infobox Treaty | name = Treaty of Eger | long_name = ''Hauptvergleich von Eger'' ([[German language|de]])
''Chebský mír'' ([[Czech language|cs]]) | image = Erzgebirge phys map de.png | image_width = 270px | caption = Ore Mountains with present Czech-German border | type = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 25 April 1459 | location_signed = [[Eger]] (Cheb), [[Egerland]] | date_sealed = | date_effective = | condition_effective = | date_expiration = | signatories = {{flagicon|Electorate of Saxony}} [[Electorate of Saxony]]
{{flagicon|Bohemia}} [[Kingdom of Bohemia]] | parties = | depositor = | languages = | website = }} The '''Treaty of Eger''' ({{lang-de|Vertrag von Eger}}), also called '''Main Compromise of Eger''' (''Hauptvergleich von Eger'') or '''Peace of Eger''' ({{lang-cs|Chebský mír}}) was concluded on 25 April 1459 in the [[Free imperial city|Imperial City]] of [[Cheb|Eger]] (''Cheb''), administrative seat of the [[Imperial immediacy|immediate]] pawn of [[Egerland]] (''Reichspfandschaft Eger''). The treaty established the border between the [[Kingdom of Bohemia]] and the [[Electorate of Saxony]] on the main ridge of the [[Ore Mountains]] stretching from Eger to the River [[Elbe]]. The border remains largely unchanged up to today, separating the [[Czech Republic]] and [[Germany]], and is thus one of the oldest still extant borders in [[Europe]]. ==Background== At that time, the [[House of Wettin|Wettin]] elector [[Frederick II, Elector of Saxony|Frederick II of Saxony]] and his brother Landgrave [[William III, Landgrave of Thuringia|William of Thuringia]] had re-arranged their dominions in the 1445 [[Division of Altenburg]] and the following [[Saxon Fratricidal War]]. In 1432 Frederick had already reached a separate peace agreement with the Bohemian [[Hussite Wars|Hussites]]. After the death of the [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] king [[Albert II of Germany]], the [[Utraquism|Utraquist]] leader [[George of Poděbrady]] had been elected Bohemian regent by local nobles in 1448 against the resistance of the [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] supporters of Albert's minor son and heir [[Ladislaus the Posthumous]], led by Burgrave [[Meinhard of Neuhaus]]. In the Saxon Fratricidal War, George had backed the younger brother Landgrave William. After the sudden death of Ladislaus, he was crowned Bohemian king by the Utraquist nobility in 1458, while William had also been a candidate for the succession. [[File:Cheb hrad 4.jpg|thumb|Ruins of Cheb Castle]] ==Agreement== In 1459 the Wettin brothers agreed with George of Poděbrady that towns, castles, markets and villages south of the Ore Mountains that formerly had belonged to the [[Lands of the Bohemian Crown]] (like [[Most (Most District)|Most]], Rýzmburk Castle at [[Osek (Teplice District)|Osek]] and [[Duchcov]]) together with all spiritual and secular bodies, pensions, interest, duties, etc. belonged to the estates of King George, whilst those estates and castles located on the northern side in the [[Vogtland]] region and the former [[Margraviate of Meissen]] should be left with the Saxon electors. Through this agreement, the border disputes that were constantly occurring were ultimately ended. That said, some places and dominions north of the Ore Mountains continued to be fiefdoms of the Bohemian crown. ==Aftermath== Upon the death of Elector Frederick II in 1464, his eldest son [[Ernest, Elector of Saxony|Ernest]] ruled jointly with his younger brother [[Albert III, Duke of Saxony|Albert]]. Their realm comprised all Wettin lands, when their uncle Landgrave William of Thuringia died without male heirs in 1482. However, by the 1485 [[Treaty of Leipzig]] the brothers again divided the Saxon lands, with the western Thuringia and Vogtland regions passing to Ernest and eastern Meissen falling to Albert. George of Poděbrady had to face the continuous resistance of the Catholic nobility backed by [[Pope Paul II]], who designated [[Matthias Corvinus]] Bohemian king in 1469. The most significant change to the border fixed by the 1459 treaty happened in 1546, when Duke [[Maurice, Elector of Saxony|Maurice of Saxony]] and King [[Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand I]] divided the [[Barony of Schwarzenberg]], former possession of Elector [[John Frederick I, Elector of Saxony|John Frederick I]], as part of the spoils of war following the [[Schmalkaldic War]], with [[Boží Dar]] and [[Horní Blatná]] passing to Bohemia. ==See also== *[[Czech Republic–Germany border]] *[[Czech Republic–Germany relations]] [[Category:History of Europe]] [[Category:Peace treaties|Eger, 1459]] [[Category:1459 in Europe]] [[Category:Cheb]] [[Category:1450s treaties]] [[Category:Treaties of the Electorate of Saxony]] [[Category:Treaties of the Kingdom of Bohemia]] [[Category:Borders of Germany]] [[Category:Borders of the Czech Republic]] [[Category:1450s in the Holy Roman Empire]] [[Category:15th century in Saxony]] [[Category:15th century in Bohemia]] [[Category:1459 in military history]]

{{Use American English|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name= United States Africa Command |image= Seal of the United States Africa Command.svg |caption= Emblem of United States Africa Command |dates= Established: 1 October 2007
Activated: 1 October 2008http://www.africom.mil/about-the-command |country= {{nowrap|{{flagu|United States|name=United States of America}}}} |type= [[Unified combatant command]] |role= |size= 2,000 (1,500 stationed at HQ in Germany){{cite web |title=About the Command |url=http://www.africom.mil/about-the-command |publisher=U.S. AFRICOM |accessdate=24 June 2015}} |command_structure={{dodseal|DOD}} [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] |garrison= [[Kelley Barracks]], [[Stuttgart]], [[Germany]] |garrison_label=Headquarters |nickname= U.S. AFRICOM, USAFRICOM |motto= |battles= [[2011 military intervention in Libya]]
[[Tongo Tongo ambush]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |website = [http://www.africom.mil www.africom.mil] |commander1= [[General (United States)|General]] [[Thomas D. Waldhauser]],
[[United States Marine Corps|USMC]] |commander1_label= Commander |commander2= Lieutenant General [[James C. Vechery]], [[United States Air Force|USAF]] |commander2_label= Deputy for Military Operations |commander3= Ambassador Alexander M. Laskaris,
[[U.S. Department of State]]{{cite web |url=http://www.africom.mil/about-the-command/leadership/deputy-to-the-commander-for-civil-military-engagement-dcme |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160510195615/http://www.africom.mil/about-the-command/leadership/deputy-to-the-commander-for-civil-military-engagement-dcme |archivedate=10 May 2016 |df=dmy-all }} |commander3_label= Deputy for
Civil-Military Engagement |notable_commanders= |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label= |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= }} The '''United States Africa Command''' ('''USAFRICOM''', '''U.S. AFRICOM''', and '''AFRICOM'''),{{Cite book|title=DOD Dictionary of Military and Associated Terms|last=|first=|publisher=U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) - Joint Chiefs of Staff - J7|year=August 2017|isbn=|location=U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff - J7, 9999 Joint Staff Pentagon #2D932, Arlington VA 22202|pages=372}} is one of ten [[Unified Combatant Command|unified combatant command]]s of the [[United States Armed Forces]], headquartered at [[Kelley Barracks]], [[Stuttgart]], [[Germany]]. It is responsible for U.S. military operations, including fighting regional conflicts{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=3WhFCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA83&lpg=PA83&dq=%22fighting+regional+conflicts%22+%22air+component+staff+never%22&source=bl&ots=u7LC8tuU7_&sig=VlW41l8nb4_1yfhwCtFCCbzLb6M&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjqr_PV1LrWAhXGa7wKHTuqB00Q6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&q=%22fighting%20regional%20conflicts%22%20%22air%20component%20staff%20never%22&f=false|title=Precision and Purpose: Airpower in the Libyan Civil War|last=Mueller|first=Karl P.|date=2015-07-08|publisher=Rand Corporation|year=|isbn=9780833087935|location=|pages=83|language=en}} and maintaining military relations with 53 African nations. Its [[area of responsibility]] covers all of [[Africa]] except [[Egypt]], which is within the area of responsibility of the [[United States Central Command]]. U.S. AFRICOM headquarters operating budget was $276 million in fiscal year 2012. The Commander of U.S. AFRICOM [[Chain of command|reports]] to the [[Secretary of Defense]].{{cite web |title=FACT SHEET: United States Africa Command |url=http://www.africom.mil/newsroom/article/6107/fact-sheet-united-states-africa-command |date=15 April 2013 |publisher=U.S. AFRICOM Office of Public Affairs |accessdate=24 June 2015}} In individual countries, [[U.S. Ambassador]]s continue to be the primary diplomatic representative for relations with host nations. ==Function== In 2007, the White House announced, "[AFRICOM] will strengthen our security cooperation with Africa and create new opportunities to bolster the capabilities of our partners in Africa. Africa Command will enhance our efforts to bring peace and security to the people of Africa and promote our common goals of development, health, education, democracy, and economic growth in Africa."{{cite web|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/02/20070206-3.html |title=President Bush Creates a Department of Defense Unified Combatant Command for Africa |publisher=Georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov |date=6 February 2007 |accessdate=19 May 2011}} General [[Carter F. Ham]] said in a 2012 address at [[Brown University]] that U.S. strategy for [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] is to strengthen democratic institutions and boost broad-based economic growth. The U.S. Africa Command is currently operating along five lines of effort: # Neutralize [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)|al-Shabaab]] and transition the security responsibilities of the [[African Union Mission in Somalia]] (AMISOM) to the [[Federal Government of Somalia]] (FGS) # Degrade violent extremist organizations in the [[Sahel]] [[Maghreb]] and contain instability in [[Libya]] # Contain and degrade [[Boko Haram]] # Interdict illicit activity in the [[Gulf of Guinea]] and [[Central Africa]] with willing and capable African partners # Build [[peacekeeping]], [[humanitarian assistance]] and [[disaster response]] capacity of African partners{{Cite book|title=United States Africa Command 2017 Posture Statement|last=Waldhauser|first=General Thomas D.|publisher=U.S. Africa Command|date=9 March 2017|isbn=|location=U.S. Senate Committee on Armed Services|pages=7}} {{PD-notice}} ==History (2000–2006)== Prior to the creation of AFRICOM, responsibility for U.S. military operations in Africa was divided across three unified commands: [[United States European Command]] (EUCOM) for West Africa, [[United States Central Command]] (CENTCOM) for East Africa, and [[United States Pacific Command]] (PACOM) for Indian Ocean waters and islands off the east coast of Africa. A U.S. military officer wrote the first public article calling for the formation of a separate African command in November 2000.{{cite journal |url=http://ssi.armywarcollege.edu/pubs/parameters/articles/00winter/catoire.htm |title=A CINC for Sub-Saharan Africa? Rethinking the Unified Command Plan |journal=Parameters |volume=Winter 2000–01 |publisher=US Army War College |accessdate=9 Nov 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109134629/http://ssi.armywarcollege.edu/pubs/parameters/articles/00winter/catoire.htm |archivedate=9 November 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Following a 2004 global posture review, the [[United States Department of Defense]] began establishing a number of [[Cooperative Security Location]]s (CSLs) and [[Forward Operating Site]]s (FOSs) across the African continent, through the auspices of EUCOM which had nominal command of West Africa at that time. These locations, along with [[Camp Lemonnier]] in [[Djibouti]], would form the basis of AFRICOM facilities on the continent. Areas of military interest to the United States in Africa include the [[Sahara]]/[[Sahel]] region,{{cite news |title=US targets Sahara 'terrorist haven' |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4749357.stm |work=BBC News |date=8 August 2005 |accessdate=24 June 2015 |first=Catherine |last=Fellows}} over which [[Joint Task Force Aztec Silence]] is conducting anti-terrorist operations ([[Operation Enduring Freedom - Trans Sahara]]), Djibouti in the Horn of Africa, where [[CJTF-HOA|Combined Joint Task Force – Horn of Africa]] is located (overseeing [[Operation Enduring Freedom - Horn of Africa]]), and the [[Gulf of Guinea]]. The website '''Magharebia.com''' was launched by USEUCOM in 2004 to provide news about North Africa in English, French and Arabic.{{cite web |title=About This Site |url=http://www.magharebia.com/cocoon/awi/xhtml1/en_GB/document/awi/footer/about/about |date=22 October 2004 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041204211810/http://www.magharebia.com/cocoon/awi/xhtml1/en_GB/document/awi/footer/about/about |archivedate=4 December 2004}} When AFRICOM was created, it took over operation of the website.{{cite news |title=U.S. Africa Command Brings New Concerns |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/27/AR2007052700978.html |date=8 May 2015 |first=Walter |last=Pincus |work=Washington Post |accessdate=25 June 2015}} Information operations of the United States Department of Defense was criticized by the Senate Armed Forces Committee and defunded by Congress in 2011. The site was closed down in February 2015.{{cite news |title=A speed bump for Pentagon's information ops |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/checkpoint-washington/post/a-speed-bump-for-pentagons-information-ops/2011/12/06/gIQAbxF7YO_blog.html |date=6 December 2011 |first=Walter |last=Pincus |work=Washington Post |accessdate=25 June 2015}}{{cite news |title=DOD shutters two 'influence' websites covering Africa |url=http://fcw.com/articles/2015/02/13/african-web-sites.aspx |first=Adam |last=Mazmanian |date=13 February 2015 |accessdate=25 June 2015 |work=FCW}} In 2007, the [[United States Congress]] approved $500 million for the [[Trans-Saharan Counterterrorism Initiative]] (TSCTI) over six years to support countries involved in [[counterterrorism]] against threats of [[Al Qaeda]] operating in African countries, primarily [[Algeria]], Chad, [[Mali]], Mauritania, [[Niger]], Senegal, [[Nigeria]], and [[Morocco]].{{cite news |title=POLITICS: Africa to Get Its Own U.S. Military Command |url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2007/01/politics-africa-to-get-its-own-us-military-command/ |work=Inter Press Service |first=Jim |last=Lobe |date=31 January 2007 |accessdate=24 June 2015}} This program builds upon the former [[Pan Sahel Initiative]] (PSI), which concluded in December 2004{{cite web |title=Operations and Initiatives |url=http://www.eucom.mil/english/Operations/main.asp |publisher=[[EUCOM]] |accessdate=6 February 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070109185740/http://www.eucom.mil/english/Operations/main.asp |archivedate=9 January 2007}} and focused on [[weapon trafficking|weapon]] and drug trafficking, as well as counterterrorism.{{cite web |title=Pan Sahel Initiative (PSI) |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/ops/pan-sahel.htm |work=GlobalSecurity.org |accessdate=24 June 2015}} Previous U.S. military activities in Sub-Saharan Africa have included Special Forces associated [[Joint Combined Exchange Training]]. Letitia Lawson, writing in 2007 for a [[Center for Contemporary Conflict]] journal at the [[Naval Postgraduate School]], noted that U.S. policy towards Africa, at least in the medium-term, looks to be largely defined by international terrorism, the increasing importance of African oil to American energy needs, and the dramatic expansion and improvement of [[Sino-African relations]] since 2000.{{cite journal |last=Lawson |first=Letitia |date=January 2007 |title=U.S. Africa Policy Since the Cold War |journal=Strategic Insights |volume=6 |issue=1 |url= http://calhoun.nps.edu/bitstream/handle/10945/11266/lawsonJan07.pdf |accessdate=24 June 2015 |publisher=Department of National Security Affairs Center on Contemporary Conflict}} ==Creation of AFRICOM (2006–2008)== In mid-2006, Defense Secretary [[Donald Rumsfeld]] formed a planning team to advise on requirements for establishing a new Unified Command for the African continent. In early December, he made his recommendations to President [[George W. Bush]].{{cite news |title=Pentagon Creates Military Command for Africa. |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=7234997 |work=[[National Public Radio|NPR Morning Edition]] |date=7 February 2007 |accessdate=25 June 2015 |first=Jackie |last=Northham}}{{cite news |title=Africa Command plans approved by Bush, DOD officials confirm |url=http://stripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=42476 |work=Stars and Stripes |date=30 December 2006 |accessdate=25 June 2015 |first=Jeff |last=Schogol}} On 6 February 2007, Defense Secretary [[Robert Gates]] announced to the [[Senate Armed Services Committee]] that President George W. Bush had given authority to create the new African Command.{{cite news |title=DoD Establishing U.S. Africa Command |url=http://www.defenselink.mil/News/NewsArticle.aspx?id=2940 |work=American Forces Press Services |publisher=[[US Department of Defense]] |date=6 February 2007 |accessdate=25 June 2015 |first=Jim |last=Garamone}} [[U.S. Navy]] [[Rear Admiral]] [[Robert Moeller]], the director of the AFRICOM transition team, arrived in Stuttgart, Germany to begin creating the logistical framework for the command.{{cite news |title=U.S. Creating New Africa Command To Coordinate Military Efforts |url=http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/article/2007/02/20070206170933mvyelwarc0.2182581.html |date=6 February 2007 |publisher=[[US Department of State]] |accessdate=25 June 2015 |work=USINFO |first=Vince |last=Crawley}}{{cite news |title=Africa Command Transition Team leader arrives in Stuttgart |url=http://www.eucom.mil/media-library/article/20948/africa-command-transition-team-leader-arrives |work=Africa Command Transition Team Public Affairs |publisher=USEUCOM |date=27 February 2007 |accessdate=25 June 2015}} On 28 September the U.S. Senate confirmed General [[William E. Ward|William E. "Kip" Ward]] as AFRICOM's first commander and AFRICOM officially became operational as a sub-unified command of EUCOM with a separate headquarters.{{cite news |url=http://www.africom.mil/NEWSROOM/Article/6042/us-africa-command-reaches-initial-operating-capabi |title=U.S. Africa Command Reaches Initial Operating Capability |date=1 October 2007 |publisher=US AFRICOM Public Affairs |accessdate=25 June 2015}} On 1 October 2008, the command separated from USEUCOM and began operating on its own as a full-fledged combatant command. ==Geographic scope== [[File:GCCMAP.png|thumb|right|300px|In this map, U.S. AFRICOM Area of Responsibility is shown in green]] [[File:USAFRICOM United States Africa Command Map Draft.jpg|thumb|right|300px|February 2007 Draft Map of U.S. AFRICOM showing its creation from parts of [[USEUCOM]], [[USCENTCOM]] and [[USINDOPACOM]].]] The territory of the command consists of all of the African continent except for [[Egypt]], which remains under the direct responsibility of USCENTCOM, as it closely relates to the Middle East. USAFRICOM also covers island countries commonly associated with Africa: * [[Cape Verde]] * [[São Tomé and Príncipe]] * [[Comoros]] * [[Madagascar]] * [[Mauritius]] * [[Seychelles]]{{cite news |title=Pentagon setting up new U.S. command to oversee African missions |url=http://helenair.com/news/national/pentagon-setting-up-new-u-s-command-to-oversee-african/article_1fd6a4bb-a254-5345-b619-3c50d6aa87c3.html |work=Independent Record |agency=Associated Press |date=6 February 2007 |accessdate=25 June 2015 |first=Pauline |last=Jelinek}} The U.S. military [[area of responsibility|areas of responsibility]] involved were transferred from three separate U.S. unified combatant commands. Most of Africa was transferred from the [[United States European Command]] with the [[East Africa|Horn of Africa]] and [[Sudan]] transferred from the [[United States Central Command]]. Responsibility for U.S. military operations in the islands of [[Madagascar]], the [[Comoros]], the [[Seychelles]] and [[Mauritius]] was transferred from the [[United States Pacific Command]]. ==Headquarters and facilities== The AFRICOM headquarters is located at [[Kelley Barracks]], a small urban facility near [[Stuttgart]], Germany, and is staffed by 1,500 personnel. In addition, the command has military and civilian personnel assigned at [[Camp Lemonnier|Camp Lemonnier, Djibouti]]; [[RAF Molesworth|RAF Molesworth, United Kingdom]]; [[MacDill Air Force Base|MacDill Air Force Base, Florida]]; and in Offices of Security Cooperation and Defense Attaché Offices in about 38 African countries. ===Selection of the headquarters=== It was reported in June 2007 that African countries were competing to host the headquarters because it would bring money for the recipient country.''[[The Economist]]'', "Policing the undergoverned spaces", 16–22 June 2007, p. 46 However, of all the African nations, only [[Liberia]] has publicly expressed a willingness to host AFRICOM's headquarters. The U.S. declared in February 2008 that AFRICOM would be headquartered in Stuttgart for the "foreseeable future". In August 2007, Dr. Wafula Okumu, a research fellow at the Institute for Security Studies in South Africa, testified before the United States Congress about the growing resistance and hostility on the African continent.{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200708031070.html?page=2 |publisher=Allafrica.com |title=Africa: Testimony of Dr. Wafula Okumu – U.S. House Africom Hearing}} [[Nigeria]] announced it will not allow its country to host a base and opposed the creation of a base on the continent. South Africa and [[Libya]] also expressed reservations of the establishment of a headquarters in Africa.{{cite web |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/02/19/africa/AF-GEN-US-Africa-Command.php |title=US AFRICOM headquarters to remain in Germany for "foreseeable future |publisher= ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'' |date= 19 February 2008}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7251648.stm |title=US drops Africa military HQ plan |publisher= ''[[BBC News]]'' |date= 18 February 2008}} The ''Sudan Tribune'' considered it likely that [[Ethiopia]], a strong U.S. ally in the region, will house USAFRICOM's headquarters due to the collocation of AFRICOM with the [[African Union]]'s developing [[Peace and Security Council|peace and security apparatus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article24660 |title=US army boss for Africa says no garrisons planned |publisher=SudanTribune article |accessdate=19 May 2011}} [[Prime Minister of Ethiopia|Prime Minister]] [[Meles Zenawi]] stated in early November that Ethiopia would be willing to work together closely with USAFRICOM.{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article24667 |title=Ethiopia ready to cooperate with US Africa Command – Zenawi |publisher=SudanTribune article |accessdate=19 May 2011}} This was further reinforced when a U.S. Air Force official said on 5 December 2007, that [[Addis Ababa]] was likely to be the headquarters.Erik Holmes, [http://www.airforcetimes.com/news/2007/12/airforce_africom_standup_071203w/ Official: AFRICOM Will Need Air Force Aircraft], Air Force Times, 5 December 2007 On 18 February 2008 General Ward told an audience at the [[Royal United Services Institute]] in London that some portion of that staff headquarters being on the continent at some point in time would be "a positive factor in helping us better deliver programs."[http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=1659 "TRANSCRIPT: General Ward Outlines Vision for U.S. Africa Command"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007034643/http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=1659 |date=7 October 2008 }}, 18 February 2008 General Ward also told the BBC the same day in an interview that there are no definite plans to take the headquarters or a portion of it to any particular location on the continent.[http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=1658 "TRANSCRIPT: AFRICOM's General Ward Interviewed by the BBC's Nick Childs"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227125058/http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=1658 |date=27 February 2008 }}, 18 February 2008 President Bush denied that the United States was contemplating the construction of new bases on the African continent.[https://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2008/02/20/ap4674005.html "Bush Says No New U.S. Bases in Africa"]{{dead link|date=May 2011}} U.S. plans include no large installations such as [[Camp Bondsteel]] in Kosovo, but rather a network of "cooperative security locations" at which temporary activities will be conducted. There is one U.S. base on the continent, [[Camp Lemonnier]] in Djibouti, with approximately 2,300 troops stationed there having been inherited from USCENTCOM upon standup of the command. In general, U.S. Unified Combatant Commands have an HQ of their own in one location, subordinate service component HQs, sometimes one or two co-located with the main HQ or sometimes spread widely, and a wide range of operating locations, main bases, forward detachments, etc. USAFRICOM initially appears to be considering something slightly different; spreading the actually [[Unified Combatant Command|COCOM]] HQ over several locations, rather than having the COCOM HQ in one place and the putative "U.S. Army Forces, Africa", its air component, and "U.S. Naval Forces, Africa" in one to four separate locations. AFRICOM will not have the traditional J-type staff divisions,{{clarify|date=March 2015}} instead having outreach, plans and programs, knowledge development, operations and logistics, and resources branches.Stars and Stripes, [http://www.estripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=55606&archive=true AFRICOM to depart from J-code structure], 12 August 2007 AFRICOM went back to a traditional J-Staff in early 2011 after General [[Carter Ham]] took command.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} ==Personnel== U.S. Africa Command completed fiscal year 2010 with approximately 2,000 assigned personnel, which includes military, civilian, contractor, and host nation employees. About 1,500 work at the command’s main headquarters in Stuttgart. Others are assigned to the command’s units in England and Florida, along with security cooperation officers posted at U.S. embassies and diplomatic missions in Africa to coordinate Defense Department programs within the host nation. As of December 2010, the command has five [[Senior Foreign Service]] officers in key positions as well as more than 30 personnel from 13 U.S. Government Departments and Agencies serving in leadership, management, and staff positions. Some of the agencies represented are the United States Departments of [[United States Department of State|State]], [[United States Department of Treasury|Treasury]], and [[United States Department of Commerce|Commerce]], [[United States Agency for International Development]], and the [[United States Coast Guard]]. U.S. Africa Command has limited assigned forces and relies on the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] for resources necessary to support its missions. ==Components== On 1 October 2008, the [[Seventeenth Air Force]] was established at [[Ramstein Air Base]], Germany as the [[United States Air Force]] component of the Africa Command.{{cite web |url=http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?F=3070041&C=america |title=U.S. AFRICOM Faces African Concerns – 10/01/07 17:39 |publisher=DefenseNews.com |accessdate=19 May 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Brig. Gen. Tracey Garrett was named as commander of the new USMC component, U.S. Marine Corps Forces Africa (MARFORAF), in November 2008.{{cite web |first1=Brigadier General Tracy L. |last1=Garrett |first2=General William E. |last2=Ward |date=14 November 2008 |title=TRANSCRIPT: Marine Corps Forces, Africa Officially Established |url=http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=2252 |accessdate=21 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720130016/http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=2252 |archivedate=20 July 2011 }}{{cite press release |title=U.S. Military Official Pays Courtesy Call |date=18 November 2008 |url=http://www.emansion.gov.lr/press.php?news_id=949 |archivedate=23 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090823030546/http://www.emansion.gov.lr/press.php?news_id=949 |publisher=[[President of Liberia|The Executive Mansion]], [[Liberia|The Republic of Liberia]] |accessdate=21 November 2008}} MARFORAF is a dual-mission arrangement for [[United States Marine Corps Forces, Europe]]. On 3 December 2008 the U.S. announced that Army and Navy headquarters units of AFRICOM would be hosted in [[Italy]]. The AFRICOM section of the Army’s [[Southern European Task Force]] would be located in [[Vicenza]] and Naval Forces Europe in [[Naples]] would expand to include the Navy's AFRICOM component.Novak, Lisa M., "Italy To Host AFRICOM Headquarters", ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]'', 5 December 2008. Special Operations Command, Africa (SOCAFRICA) is also established, gaining control over Joint Special Operations Task Force-Trans Sahara (JSOTF-TS) and Special Operations Command and Control Element – Horn of Africa (SOCCE-HOA).Special Operations Technology, [http://www.special-operations-technology.com/sotech-archives/58-sotech-2008-volume-6-issue-6/438-qaa-brigadier-general-patrick-m-higgins.html Q & A with Brigadier General Patrick M. Higgins] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716114323/http://www.special-operations-technology.com/sotech-archives/58-sotech-2008-volume-6-issue-6/438-qaa-brigadier-general-patrick-m-higgins.html |date=16 July 2011 }}, Vol. 6, Issue 6, 2008 The U.S. Army has allocated a brigade to the Africa Command.[http://www.army.mil/article/92623/_Fiscal_Cliff__would_challenge_Army_to_maintain_readiness/ Lt. Gen. William Grisoli, "The Army has now aligned a brigade with U.S. Africa Command."] accessdate=2012-12-10 ===U.S. Army Africa (USARAF)=== [[File:U.S. Army Africa Shoulder Sleeve Insignia.jpg|right|150px|U.S. Army Africa]] Headquartered on Caserma Ederle in Vicenza, Italy, [[U.S. Army Africa]], in concert with national and international partners, conducts sustained security engagement with African land forces to promote peace, stability, and security in Africa. As directed, it can deploy as a contingency headquarters in support of crisis response.{{cite web |url=http://www.usaraf.army.mil/welcome.html |title=Welcome Information – US Army Africa |publisher=Usaraf.army.mil |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718134920/http://www.usaraf.army.mil/welcome.html |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The [[2nd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division (United States)|2nd Brigade Combat Team, 1st Infantry Division]], the "Dagger Brigade", is being aligned with AFRICOM.{{cite web |url=http://www.army.mil/article/96824/_Dagger__brigade_readies_for_AFRICOM_missions/ |title=Dagger brigade readies for AFRICOM missions |publisher=Army.mil |accessdate=2013-03-02}} ===U.S. Naval Forces, Africa (NAVAF)=== [[File:NavyAfrica.png|right|150px|U.S. Naval Forces Africa]] [[U.S. Naval Forces Europe - Naval Forces Africa]] (NAVEUR-NAVAF) area of responsibility (AOR) covers approximately half of the Atlantic Ocean, from the North Pole to Antarctica; as well as the Adriatic, Baltic, Barents, Black, Caspian, Mediterranean and North Seas.{{cite web|url=http://www.naveur-navaf.navy.mil |title=Commander, U.S. Naval Forces Europe-Africa/U.S. 6th Fleet |publisher=Naveur-navaf.navy.mil |date=21 December 2008 |accessdate=19 May 2011}} NAVEUR-NAVAF covers all of [[Russia]], Europe and nearly the entire continent of Africa. It encompasses 105 countries with a combined population of more than one billion people and includes a landmass extending more than 14 million square miles. The area of responsibility covers more than 20 million square nautical miles of ocean, touches three continents and encompasses more than 67 percent of the Earth's coastline, 30 percent of its landmass, and nearly 40 percent of the world's population.{{cite web|url=http://www.naveur-navaf.navy.mil/AORPAGE.html |title=CNE NAV Left Navigation |publisher=Naveur-navaf.navy.mil |date=21 December 2008 |accessdate=19 May 2011}} [[Task Force 60]] will normally be the commander of Naval Task Force Europe and Africa.{{citation needed|reason=footnote 20 was copied. Needs actual footnote|date=November 2012}} Any naval unit within the USEUCOM or USAFRICOM AOR may be assigned to Task Force 60 as required upon by the Commander of the [[United States Sixth Fleet|Sixth Fleet]]. ===U.S. Air Forces Africa (AFAFRICA)=== [[File:US Air Forces Africa (emblem).png|right|150px|U.S. Air Forces Africa]] [[Air Forces Africa]] ([[AFAFRICA]]) is located at [[Ramstein Air Base]], Germany, and serves as the air and space component to U.S. Africa Command (AFRICOM) located at Stuttgart, Germany. [[Air Forces Africa]] shares a headquarters and units with [[United States Air Forces in Europe]], and its component Air Force, 3AF (AFAFRICA) conducts sustained security engagement and operations as directed to promote air safety, security and development on the African continent. Through its Theater Security Cooperation (TSC) events, Air Forces Africa carries out AFRICOM's policy of seeking long-term partnership with the African Union and regional organizations as well as individual nations on the continent.{{cite web |url=http://www.17af.usafe.af.mil |title=17th Air Force – Home |publisher=17af.usafe.af.mil |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110510065439/http://www.17af.usafe.af.mil/ |archivedate=10 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Air Forces Africa works with other U.S. Government agencies, to include the State Department and the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), to assist African partners in developing national and regional security institution capabilities that promote security and stability and facilitate development.{{cite web |url=http://newpreview.afnews.af.mil/17af/index.asp |title=17th Air Force – Home |publisher=Newpreview.afnews.af.mil |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119093329/http://newpreview.afnews.af.mil/17af/index.asp |archivedate=19 January 2016 |df=dmy-all }} 3AF succeeds the [[Seventeenth Air Force]] by assuming the [[AFAFRICA]] mission upon the 17AF's deactivation on 20 April 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.usafe.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123300193 |title=17th Air Force stands down, AFAFRICA mission carries on |publisher=U.S. Air Forces in Europe Public Affairs |accessdate=1 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526230855/http://www.usafe.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123300193 |archivedate=26 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }} ===U.S. Marine Corps Forces, Africa (MARFORAF)=== [[File:U.S. Marine Corps Forces Africa.png|right|150px|U.S. Marine Corps Forces Africa]] U.S. Marine Corps Forces, Africa conducts operations, exercises, training, and security cooperation activities throughout the AOR. In 2009, MARFORAF participated in 15 ACOTA missions aimed at improving partners’ capabilities to provide logistical support, employ military police, and exercise command and control over deployed forces. MARFORAF conducted military to military events in 2009 designed to familiarize African partners with nearly every facet of military operations and procedures, including use of unmanned aerial vehicles, tactics, and medical skills. MARFORAF, as the lead component, continues to conduct Exercise AFRICAN LION in Morocco—the largest annual Combined Joint Chiefs of Staff (CJCS) exercise on the African continent—as well as Exercise SHARED ACCORD 10, which was the first CJCS exercise conducted in Mozambique.{{cite web |url=http://marines.mil/unit/marforaf/Pages/mission.aspx |title=Mission |publisher=Marines.mil |date=6 February 2007 |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511053753/http://www.marines.mil/unit/marforaf/Pages/mission.aspx |archivedate=11 May 2011 |df=dmy-all }} In 2013, the [[Special Purpose Marine Air-Ground Task Force - Crisis Response - Africa]] was formed to provide quick response to American interests in North Africa by flying marines in [[Bell Boeing V-22 Osprey]] aircraft from bases in Europe.{{cite web|url=http://www.marforaf.marines.mil/News/NewsArticleDisplay/tabid/5697/Article/144682/sp-magtf-crisis-response-ace-maintains-readiness-24-7.aspx |title=SP-MAGTF Crisis Response ACE maintains readiness 24/ 7 |publisher=Marforaf.marines.mil |date= |accessdate=2014-05-12}} ==Subordinate Commands== ===U.S. Special Operations Command, Africa=== [[File:SOCAFRICA Logo.jpg|right|150px|Special Operations Command Africa: United States Army Element Shoulder Sleeve Insignia and Combat Service Identification Badge]] Special Operations Command Africa was activated on 1 October 2008 and became fully operationally capable on 1 October 2009. SOCAFRICA is a Subordinate-Unified Command of [[United States Special Operations Command]], operationally controlled by U.S. Africa Command, collocated with USAFRICOM at Kelley Barracks, Stuttgart-Möhringen, Germany. Also on 1 October 2008, SOCAFRICA assumed responsibility for the Special Operations Command and Control Element – Horn of Africa, and on 15 May 2009, SOCAFRICA assumed responsibility for [[Joint Special Operations Task Force Trans – Sahara]] (JSOTF-TS) – the SOF component of [[Operation Enduring Freedom – Trans Sahara]]. SOCAFRICA’s objectives are to build operational capacity, strengthen regional security and capacity initiatives, implement effective communication strategies in support of strategic objectives, and eradicate violent extremist organizations and their supporting networks. SOCAFRICA forces work closely with both U.S. Embassy country teams and African partners, maintaining a small but sustained presence throughout Africa, predominantly in the OEF-TS and CJTF-HOA regions. SOCAFRICA’s persistent SOF presence provides an invaluable resource that furthers USG efforts to combat violent extremist groups and builds partner nation CT capacity.{{cite web |url=http://www.africom.mil/pdfFiles/USAFRICOM2010PostureStatement.pdf |title=Report |format=PDF |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720131203/http://www.africom.mil/pdfFiles/USAFRICOM2010PostureStatement.pdf |archivedate=20 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} On 8 April 2011, Naval Special Warfare Unit 10, operationally assigned and specifically dedicated for SOCAFRICA missions, was commissioned at [[Panzer Kaserne]], near Stuttgart, Germany.{{cite web |url=http://www.africom.mil/Newsroom/Article/8250/nswu-10-commissioning-provides-socafrica-operation |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023234652/http://www.africom.mil/Newsroom/Article/8250/nswu-10-commissioning-provides-socafrica-operation |archivedate=23 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }} It is administratively assigned to [[Naval Special Warfare Group 2]] on the U.S. East Coast. Organizations included in SOCAFRICA include:SOCOM 2015 Factbook *Special Operations Command Forward—East (Special Operations Command and Control Element—Horn of Africa) *Special Operations Command Forward—Central (AFRICOM Counter—[[Lord's Resistance Army]] Control Element) *Special Operations Command Forward—West (Joint Special Operations Task Force—Trans Sahara) *Naval Special Warfare Unit 10, Joint Special Operations Air Component Africa, and SOCAFRICA Signal Detachment *Commander SOCAFRICA serves as the Special Operations Adviser to Commander, USAFRICOM. ===Combined Joint Task Force – Horn of Africa=== [[File:CJTF-HOA.png|right|150px|Combined Joint Task Force – Horn of Africa]] [[Combined Joint Task Force – Horn of Africa]] (CJTF-HOA) conducts operations in the East Africa region to build partner nation capacity in order to promote regional security and stability, prevent conflict, and protect U.S. and coalition interests. CJTF-HOA's efforts, as part of a comprehensive whole-of-government approach, are aimed at increasing African partner nations' capacity to maintain a stable environment, with an effective government that provides a degree of economic and social advancement for its citizens.{{cite web |url=http://www.hoa.africom.mil/AboutCJTF-HOA.asp |title=CJTF-HOA Factsheet |publisher=Hoa.africom.mil |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426223216/http://www.hoa.africom.mil/AboutCJTF-HOA.asp |archivedate=26 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ==Programs and operations== ===Programs=== * [[African Contingency Operations Training and Assistance]] * [[Africa Partnership Station]] is the U.S. Africa Command's primary maritime security engagement program which strengthens maritime security through maritime training with various nations. * [[Combating Terrorism Fellowship Program]] * [[Pandemic Response Program]] * [[State Partnership Program]] connects a U.S. state’s National Guard to an African nation for military training and relationship-building. ===Operations=== * [[Operation Enduring Freedom - Horn of Africa]] * [[Operation Enduring Freedom - Trans Sahara]] * [[Operation Ocean Shield]] - [[Indian Ocean]] * [[Operation Odyssey Dawn]] - [[Libya]], was the first major combat deployment directed by Africa Command.Ham, Carter. [http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=6222 "STATEMENT: AFRICOM Commander on Commencement of Military Strikes in Libya."] ''AFRICOM'', 19 March 2011. * [[Operation Onward Liberty]] - [[Liberia]] * [[Operation Unified Protector]] - [[Libya]] * [[Battle of Sirte (2016)|Operation Odyssey Lightning]] - [[Libya]]{{cite web|url=http://www.libyanexpress.com/us-africom-ends-military-operation-against-is-radicals-in-libya/|title=US AFRICOM ends military operation against IS radicals in Libya|publisher= Libyan Express|date=21 December 2016|accessdate=30 December 2016}} ==List of commanders== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Waldhauser]] |[[U.S. Marine Corps]] |18 July 2016 |Incumbent |{{date difference|2016|7|18}} days |} The current State Department Deputy to the Commander for Civil-Military Engagement is Ambassador [[Alexander Laskaris]]. {{Portal|Military history of Africa|Military of the United States}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * "AFRICOM Arrives", ''[[Jane's Defence Weekly]]'', 1 October 2008 * {{cite journal |last=McFate |first=Sean |date= January 2008|title=US Africa Command: next step or next stumble? |journal=[[African Affairs]] |volume=107 |issue=426 |pages=111–120 |doi=10.1093/afraf/adm084}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{Official website|http://www.africom.mil/ }} and [https://web.archive.org/web/20110720130709/http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=4133&lang=0 March 2010 posture statement] * [http://www.usaraf.army.mil/ United States Army Africa official website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100117005910/http://www.usaraf.army.mil/MAP_INTERACTIVE/INTERACTIVE_MAP.swf Africa Interactive Map] from the [[United States Army Africa]] * [http://community.apan.org/apcn/default.aspx/ APCN (Africa Partner Country Network)] * {{cite web|url= https://www.senate.gov/~armed_services/statemnt/2007/September/Ward%2009-27-07.pdf |title=Advanced Questions for General William E. revision.comment: Changing [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]] from "Archaean supercontinent from about 3.1 billion years ago" to "Proposed archaean supercontinent from about 3.1 billion years ago" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Proposed archaean supercontinent from about 3.1 billion years ago}} {{refimprove|date=December 2016}} {{Life timeline}} '''Ur''' is a proposed supercontinent that formed in the [[Archean]] {{mya|3100}} (3.1 billion).
In Roger's reconstruction{{specify}} Ur is half a billion years older than [[Arctica]] and, in the early period of its existence, it was probably the only continent on [[Earth]], and as such can be considered a [[supercontinent]], though it was probably smaller than present-day [[Australia (continent)|Australia]]. In more recent works geologists often refer to both Ur and other proposed Archaean continental assemblages as supercratons. Ur can, nevertheless, be half a billion years younger than [[Vaalbara]], but the concepts of these two early cratonic assemblages are incompatible.
==Incompatible reconstructions== About 1,300–1,071 Mya, Ur joined the continents [[Nena (supercontinent)|Nena]] and [[Atlantica]] to form the supercontinent [[Rodinia]].<ref name>{{Harvnb|Rogers|Santosh|2003|loc=Rodinia, pp. 363–364}}</ref> In the reconstruction of {{Harvnb|Rogers|1996}}, Ur remained the nucleus of East [[Gondwana]] until the break-up of Gondwana. In other reconstructions, however, India and East Antarctica did not collide until Rodinia formed 1,071 Mya.<ref>{{Harvnb|Zhao|Cawood|Wilde|Sun|2002|loc=Implications for a pre-Rodinia supercontinent, p. 155}}</ref> Furthermore, in the Early Archaean Earth's mantle was 200 °C hotter than today and many characteristics of modern tectonics, such as [[ophiolite]]s, [[blueschist]]s, [[lawsonite]]-bearing [[eclogite]]s, and [[Ultra-high-pressure metamorphism|ultra-high-pressure rocks]], did not exist or were rare. This makes most proposed Archaean supercontinents controversial, including Rogers's 3 Gya supercontinent.<ref>{{Harvnb|Nance|Murphy|Santosh|2014|loc=Pre-Rodinia supercontinents, pp. 11–13}}</ref>
Reconstructions of the supercontinent [[Vaalbara]] places two cratons, [[Kaapvaal Craton|Kaapvaal]] in southern Africa and [[Pilbara Craton|Pilbara]] in western Australia next to each other based on stratigraphic similarities. In Roger's configuration of Ur, these cratons are placed far apart in their Gondwana configuration. This configuration is contradicted by widespread Precambrian collisional events between Australia and Africa.<ref>{{Harvnb|de Kock|Evans|Beukes|2009|loc=Introduction, p. 145}}</ref>
Yet another possible supercraton, Zimgarn, proposed by {{Harvnb|Smirnov|Evans|Ernst|Söderlund|2013}} and named after the [[Zimbabwe Craton|Zimbabwe]] and Yilgarn cratons, is distinct from both Vaalbara and Ur. Vaalbara and Zimgarn, according to this proposal, both disintegrated about 2.1–2.0 Gya to reassemble as the [[Kalahari Craton|Kalahari]] and West Australian cratons 2.524–1.507 Gya. Smirnov et al. based this reconstruction on: (1) Zimgarn was still undergoing cratonisation when an extensive [[carbonate platform]] developed over Vaalbara; (2) the magmatic signatures are different for the two supercratons during the period 2.6–2.0 Gya; and (3) paleomagnetic latitudes for 2.69 Gya are slightly different.<ref>{{Harvnb|Smirnov|Evans|Ernst|Söderlund|2013|loc=Abstract; Discussion and conclusions, pp. 15–16}}</ref>
==Original concept and later interpretations== Important geological similarities link now remote Archaean cratons in India (Singhbhum and Dharwar), western Australia (Kilbaran and Pilbara), and southern Africa (Kaapvaal and Zimbabwe) which indicate that these [[protolith]]ic shields were close together in the Mid-Archaean. The name "Ur", from the German prefix ''[[wikt|ur-]]'' meaning "original", was introduced by {{Harvnb|Rogers|1993}}, since it is the first continent in his tectonic reconstructions.<ref name="Rogers-1996">{{Harvnb|Rogers|1996|loc=Proposed Continents and Their Duration, pp. 94-95}}</ref> Other Archaean continental assemblages are considerably younger: [[Arctica]] ([[Baltica]], [[Laurentia]], Ur, and [[Siberia (continent)|Siberia]]) consolidated around ~2.565 Gya, [[Atlantica]] ([[West African Craton|West Africa]] and [[Amazonian Craton|eastern South America]]) consolidated around 2.11 Gya. In some reconstructions the shields of Ur stayed near each other until the Mesozoic break-up of Gondwana.<ref>{{Harvnb|Mondal|Piper|Hunt|Bandyopadhyay|2009|loc=The ‘Ur’ protocontinent, pp. 503–505}}</ref>
The cratons that had become stable around 3 Gya were all in the same region within Pangaea, which is the main argument for them having formed a single continent 3 billion years ago. The [[Kaapvaal Craton|Kaapvaal craton]] in southern Africa became stable around 3.1 Gya. The [[Pilbara Craton|Pilbara craton]] in western Australia is not well defined but formed around 3 Gya. Three cratons in East Antarctica are of similar age but not well known. These cratons share similar geological histories and are therefore assumed to have formed the continent [[Vaalbara]].<ref name="RogSan-2003">{{Harvnb|Rogers|Santosh|2003|loc=Ur (~3000 Ma), pp. 358–360}}</ref>
Three small areas in the Indian Ocean coast of Antarctica are also about 3 Gya old: western [[Dronning Maud Land]], the [[Napier Mountains|Napier complex]], and the [[Vestfold Hills]]. Within Gondwana, these areas were in a belt of [[Grenville orogeny|Grenville]]-age deformation, and because there is no evidence of ocean closure in this belt (except in Africa), the 1 Ga orogen can be assumed to be intra-continental. Consequently, the southern margin of Ur is now below the Antarctic ice cover.<ref name="Rogers-1996" />
Two cratons in India of equal age, [[Dharwar Craton|Western Dharwar]] and [[Singhbhum Craton|Singhbhum]], were also part of Ur. Two other Indian cratons, Eastern Dharwar and [[Bhandara Craton|Bhandara]], also formed around 3 Gya but underwent extensive magmatism around 2.5 Gya not seen elsewhere and their relation to Ur is unclear. Ur, nevertheless, became larger around 2.524 Mya, and this so-called "Expanded Ur" incorporated the [[Zimbabwe Craton]] in Africa and the [[Yilgarn Craton]] in Australia.<ref name="RogSan-2003" />
The largest preserved parts of Ur are now in India: [[Aravalli Range|Aravalli]], [[Dharwar Craton|Dharwar]], [[Bundelkhand]], and [[Singhbhum]]. The [[Central Indian Tectonic Zone]] is the modern [[Suture (geology)|suture]] between the Bundelkhand-Aravalli block and the other Archaean blocks. 2.8–2.6 Gya metamorphism in Dharwar and Bundelkhand indicate that the stabilisation of Ur probably continued until the end of that period.<ref>{{Harvnb|Mahapatro|Pant|Bhowmik|Tripathy|2012|loc=Implication for Ur Assembly, pp. 329–330}}</ref>

The '''Zenne Group''' ({{lang-nl|Zenne Groep}}) is a [[group (stratigraphy)|group]] of [[stratum|rock strata]] in the [[Subsurface (geology)|subsurface]] of central and northwest [[Belgium]]. The group consists of three [[formation (stratigraphy)|formations]], all from the [[Ypresian]] and [[Lutetian]] [[age (geology)|ages]] (early [[Eocene]], 50 to 40 million years old). These formation have their shallow marine [[sedimentary facies|facies]] in common.
The three formations are: *the [[Aalter Formation]], greenish [[sand]]s and [[clay]]s, found in [[East-Flanders]] and [[West-Flanders]]. *the [[Brussel Formation]], [[marl]]s and sands, found in [[Flemish Brabant|Flemish]] and [[Walloon Brabant]], [[Hainaut (province)|Hainaut]] and [[Namur (province)|Namur]]. *the [[Lede Formation]], calcareous sands, found in almost all central Belgium.
Stratigraphically on top of the Zenne Group are the late Eocene sands and clays of the [[Maldegem Formation]], which is not divided into a group. The Zenne Group is almost everywhere found on top of the early Eocene [[Ieper Group]].
==References== *{{aut|Laga, P.; Louwye, S. & Geets, S.}} (eds.); 2001: ''Paleogene and Neogene lithostratigraphic units (Belgium)'', Geologica Belgica 4(1-2), p. 135-152

revision.text:
'''Šakali''' (''[[Jackals]]'', also written ''Cakali'') was a [[Serbia]]n [[paramilitary]] group that operated during the [[Kosovo War]] 1999.<ref name=B92-1>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/crimes-article.php?yyyy=2010&mm=03&dd=13&nav_id=65769 |title=News - Arrests made for Kosovo crimes |publisher=B92 |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
==Ćuška massacre== {{Further|Ćuška massacre}} Nine people of the group were arrested March 13, 2010 suspected of having committed crimes in [[Ćuška]] near [[Peć]] on May 14, 1999. A trial in [[Belgrade]] started on 20 December 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/09/20109111535606107.html |title=Nine indicted over Kosovo massacre - Europe |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2010-09-11 |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulftoday.ae/portal/323f2c07-c48b-45c5-88da-90bf374339e7.aspx |title=Serb war crimes suspect arrested |publisher=gulftoday.ae |date=2010-12-25 |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref> The trial included:<ref name="balkaninsight1"/> * Srećko Popović<ref>{{cite web|author=American Council for Kosovo |url=http://www.savekosova.org/serbian=terror=12.htm |title=American Council for Kosovo - A Village Destroyed: War Crimes in Kosova |publisher=Savekosova.org |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hrc.berkeley.edu/specialprojects/avillagedestroyed/thecase/thecase_perpetrators.html |title=Human Rights Center |publisher=Hrc.berkeley.edu |date=2011-03-18 |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/legacy/reports/2001/kosovo/ |title=UNDER ORDERS: War Crimes in Kosovo |publisher=Hrw.org |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref> * Slaviša Kastratović * Boban Bogićević * Radoslav Brnović * Vidoje Korićanin * Veljko Korićanin * Abdulah Sokić
They are accused of committing murders, rapes and robberies in an "extremely brutal" way, with "the main goal to spread fear among Albanian civilians in order to force them to leave their homes and flee to Albania." [[Hasan Ceku]] the father of the former Kosovo prime minister and wartime commander of the Kosovo Liberation Army, [[Agim Ceku]], as well as several members of his family were among the murdered people.<ref name="balkaninsight1">{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/accused-serb-paramilitaries-go-on-trial-in-belgrade |title=Accused Serb Paramilitaries Go on Trial in Belgrade |publisher=Balkan Insight |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expatica.com/de/news/german-news/serb-paramilitary-held-in-germany_119599.html |title=Serb paramilitary held in Germany |publisher=Expatica.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/6736901-serbia-charges-nine-exjackals-with-war-crimes-in-kosovo/content/59675932-serbia-wants-to-continue-negotiations-on-the-status-of-kosovo |title=Serbia Charges Nine Ex-Jackals With War Crimes In Kosovo |publisher=Allvoices.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naslovi.net/2010-09-11/blic/podignuta-optuznica-za-ratni-zlocin-u-selu-cuska/1972943 |title=Podignuta optužnica za ratni zločin u selu Ćuška - Blic |publisher=Naslovi.net |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
The leader [[Nebojša Minić]] was arrested in [[Argentina]] in 2005 under a warrant of the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia|Hague Tribunal]], but died shortly of [[AIDS]] after the arrest.<ref>http://www.eip-news.com/2010/12/kosovo-former-serb-paramilitary-unit-goes-on-trial-accused-of-albanian-slaughter/</ref>
Zoran Obradović was arrested in Germany on 25 December 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emg.rs/en/news/serbia/142805.html |title=Vukcevic: Sakali member Zoran Obradovic arrested :: EMG :: Business news from Serbia 2010 |publisher=Emg.rs |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emg.rs/en/news/serbia/142805.html |title=Vukcevic: Sakali member Zoran Obradovic arrested :: EMG :: Business news from Serbia 2010 |publisher=Emg.rs |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>http://ca.news.yahoo.com/serbia-prosecutor-says-man-sought-war-crimes-kosovo-20101224-054130-015.html</ref>
Milojko Nikolić, nickname ''Sumadija'', was arrested on 28 December 2010 in Montenegro.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://internationalwarcrimesreport.wordpress.com/2010/12/28/serbian-war-crimes-suspect-arrested-in-montenegro/ |title=Serbian War Crimes Suspect Arrested in Montenegro | International War Crimes Report |publisher=Internationalwarcrimesreport.wordpress.com |date=2010-12-28 |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref name="presstv1">{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/157601.html |title=PressTV - Serb war crimes suspect detained |publisher=Presstv.ir |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kurir-info.rs/crna-hronika/uhapsen-jos-jedan-sakal-u-crnoj-gori-67065.php |title=Uhapšen još jedan šakal u Crnoj Gori - Crna hronika | Kurir |publisher=Kurir-info.rs |date= |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.montenews.me/vijesti/drustvo/99628.html |title=Crna Gora vijesti - UhapĹĄen "Ĺ akal" |publisher=MonteNews.me |date=2010-12-29 |accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
